1.name: Perceivable
1.description: Information and user interface components must be presentable to users in ways they can perceive.

1.name: Text Alternatives
1.description: Provide text alternatives for any non-text content.

1.name: Non-text Content
1.description: All non-text content has a text alternative that serves the equivalent purpose.

1.name: Audio-only and Video-only (Prerecorded)
1.description: Alternatives are provided for time-based media.

2.name: Captions (Prerecorded)
2.description: Captions are provided for all prerecorded audio content in synchronized media.

3.name: Audio Description or Media Alternative (Prerecorded)
3.description: An alternative for time-based media or audio description is provided for prerecorded video content.

3.name: Adaptable
3.description: Create content that can be presented in different ways without losing information or structure.

1.name: Info and Relationships
1.description: Information, structure, and relationships conveyed through presentation can be programmatically determined.

2.name: Meaningful Sequence
2.description: When the sequence of content affects its meaning, a correct reading sequence can be programmatically determined.

3.name: Sensory Characteristics
3.description: Instructions provided do not rely solely on sensory characteristics of components.

4.name: Distinguishable
4.description: Make it easier for users to see and hear content including separating foreground from background.

1.name: Use of Color
1.description: Color is not used as the only visual means of conveying information.

2.name: Audio Control
2.description: If any audio plays automatically for more than 3 seconds, a mechanism is available to pause or stop it.

2.name: Operable
2.description: User interface components and navigation must be operable.

1.name: Keyboard Accessible
1.description: Make all functionality available from a keyboard.

1.name: Keyboard
1.description: All functionality is available from a keyboard.

2.name: No Keyboard Trap
2.description: Keyboard focus can be moved away from a component using only a keyboard.

4.name: Character Key Shortcuts
4.description: If a keyboard shortcut uses only letter, punctuation, number, or symbol characters, then the shortcut can be turned off, remapped, or is only active when the component is focused.

2.name: Enough Time
2.description: Provide users enough time to read and use content.

1.name: Timing Adjustable
1.description: Users are given adequate time to interact with web content.

2.name: Pause, Stop, Hide
2.description: Users can pause, stop, or hide content that starts automatically and lasts more than 5 seconds.

3.name: Seizures and Physical Reactions
3.description: Do not design content in a way that is known to cause seizures or physical reactions.

1.name: Three Flashes or Below Threshold
1.description: Web pages do not contain anything that flashes more than three times in any one second period.

4.name: Navigable
4.description: Provide ways to help users navigate, find content, and determine where they are.

1.name: Bypass Blocks
1.description: A mechanism is available to bypass blocks of content that are repeated on multiple Web pages.

2.name: Page Titled
2.description: Web pages have titles that describe topic or purpose.

3.name: Focus Order
3.description: Components receive focus in an order that preserves meaning and operability.

4.name: Link Purpose (In Context)
4.description: The purpose of each link can be determined from the link text alone or from the link text together with its programmatically determined link context.

5.name: Input Modalities
5.description: Make it easier for users to operate functionality through various inputs beyond keyboard.

1.name: Pointer Gestures
1.description: All functionality that uses multipoint or path-based gestures can be operated with a single pointer.

2.name: Pointer Cancellation
2.description: Functions that can be operated using a single pointer are completed when the user releases the pointer.

3.name: Label in Name
3.description: For user interface components with labels that include text or images of text, the name contains the text that is presented visually.

4.name: Motion Actuation
4.description: Functionality that can be operated by device motion or user motion can also be operated by user interface components.

3.name: Understandable
3.description: Information and the operation of the user interface must be understandable.

1.name: Readable
1.description: Make text content readable and understandable.

1.name: Language of Page
1.description: The default human language of each page can be programmatically determined.

2.name: Predictable
2.description: Make Web pages appear and operate in predictable ways.

1.name: On Focus
1.description: When any user interface component receives focus, it does not initiate a change of context.

2.name: On Input
2.description: Changing the setting of any user interface component does not automatically cause a change of context.

3.name: Input Assistance
3.description: Help users avoid and correct mistakes.

1.name: Error Identification
1.description: If an input error is automatically detected, the item that is in error is identified and the error is described to the user in text.

2.name: Labels or Instructions
2.description: Labels or instructions are provided when content requires user input.

4.name: Robust
4.description: Content must be robust enough to be interpreted by a wide variety of user agents, including assistive technologies.

1.name: Compatible
1.description: Maximize compatibility with current and future user agents, including assistive technologies.

1.name: Parsing
1.description: In content implemented using markup languages, elements have complete start and end tags, elements are nested according to their specifications, and IDs are unique.

2.name: Name, Role, Value
2.description: For all user interface components, the name and role can be programmatically determined; states, properties, and values can be programmatically set.
